node.text:
“The earth has music for those who listen.” ~ William Shakespeare 🎵

It’s #WorldListeningDay!

How would you describe the earth’s music? What simple, or profound, messages have you received from her?

We give value to the sounds we hear—whether that is through our attention and focus, or the value or perception we afford to that sound. We can also choose to give value to the sound of, by setting aside space for—silence. 

The Grand Canyon provides us an incredible opportunity to listen. We can:
💎 Listen to the brilliant sparkle of the night skies. 
💎 Listen for birds as they express their unique songs, calls, flight patterns or movements.
💎 Listen, and feel for, when the winds start to pick up in their intensity. 
💎 Listen to the gentle caress, or raging roar, of the Colorado River as it continues its timeless generosity and continuous flow. 
💎 Listen to the Canyon open up with wonder, as the golden hues of a sunset paint the horizon in an unearthly awe. 
💎 Listen as a ranger shares with us their passion for the Canyon, as we hear their voice rise with gusto and their palpable excitement. 
💎 Listen to, and learn from, the spoken (or unspoken) histories that intimately connect indigenous people through their sacred connection to this land and this place. 

Silence is not the absence of sound but the presence of one’s ability to listen. So, today, gift yourself some moments for silence. You may find that in silence, you open up to an entire world that is waiting to share in her musical splendor with you!

For additional listening and viewing opportunities from the Grand Canyon, check out our “Minute Out In It” video series, which features compelling stories (told without words) of the diverse soundscapes and landscapes throughout the park. https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/photosmultimedia/minute-out-in-it.htm

- AB

#WorldListeningDay #ListenUp #ListenIn #Soundscapes 

[#VideoDescription: Watching cloud shadows pass lazily across the layers of the canyon during the winter season.]

NPS Video/R. Lane

An audio-described version of the film can be found here: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=772643A9-9D3B-4B0E-B6DC-D90C1DEB262E

node.title: World Listening Day: Minute Out In It In the Clouds

node.text:
Our Branch Chief of Emergency Services has an important message for you!

Grand Canyon National Park is in an Excessive Heat Warning. Inner Canyon temperatures are reaching as high as 120°F (48.9°C)! 

Your body cannot cool itself or replenish its water or salt in these conditions. Please take a look at this short video addressing heat illness, heat stroke, and how best to visit Grand Canyon during these dog days of summer.

For an audio described version and captions visit: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=A0226CAB-9569-438C-BD0C-6514B142EF28

For more information on summer hiking visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/hike-smart.htm

#RecreateResponsibly #HikeSmart

node.text:
As we get ready for Memorial Day Weekend and park visitation increases, we’d like to remind you that May is Wildland Fire Awareness Month. 

As public lands have started announcing fire restrictions in preparation for another hot and dry summer, we want to share with you a story that has become all too common. Whether you want a fire for ambience, heat, or marshmallow roasting, it is incredibly important to know if your fire is legal and safe—fires should never be started to burn waste. 

For more information and current fire restrictions visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/management/firemanagement.htm 

For closed captioned and audio described versions of this video visit: 
https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=813BBAB5-1F03-4702-8823-AF8D16D646FA 

#WildlandFireAwarenessMonth #FireSafety #MemorialDay

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 30, 2021. May be an image of African daisy and nature.

node.text:
Here’s to that #FridayFeeling! How will you connect with nature this weekend? (I’m in awe of her.)

- AB 

[#ImageDescription: A composite of 3 photos—a waterfall flows over moss-covered rocks deep within the inner canyon at Ribbon Falls on 6/11/21, NPS Photo/A. Wilson; geometric patterning of an inner agave plant, NPS Photo/C. Brennan; flowers blooming in colors of pink and white from the crown of an Arizona Fishhook Cactus, NPS Photo/K. Ceballos, Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument.]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 30, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
“Sunset is still my favorite color, and rainbow is second.” ― Mattie Stepanek 🌅 🌈🌈

[#ImageDescription: A double rainbow bursts forth with exceptional vibrancy over a vast and colorful canyon. Photo courtesy of J. Dawson]

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 29, 2021. May be an image of bird, outdoors and text.

node.text:
Consistent with CDC guidance regarding areas of substantial or high transmission, visitors to Grand Canyon National Park, regardless of vaccination status, are required to wear a mask inside all park buildings.

#RecreateResponsibly

[#ImageDescription: Composite photo of a Great Horned Owl fledgling peering around the limb of a tree, alongside an information graphic of a masked owl reading “Owl Wear One.”]

NPS Photo/N. Herbert

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 28, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.

node.text:
“I saw the Grand Canyon as one hears an exquisite poem, a soft strain of music on violin, cello or oboe, or sung by the human voice…It affected one as beautiful as flowers do, as the blessing of an old man or woman, as the half unconscious caress of a sleepy child whom you love.” – George Wharton James, 1910

Have you been affected in a similar way by your own experience of the Grand Canyon? 💖

Blooming cacti remind us that life can be both beautiful and prickly. Do we choose to focus on the beauty of the flowers, or their glochids (barbed bristles)? Both are present; each have their gifts. 

Upon first glance, we may not appreciate those barbed, prickly glochids. Yet, upon deeper examination, we realize glochids help the plant to conserve moisture, as well providing a formidable defense strategy. 

To connect with more Grand Canyon Wildflowers, visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/nature/wildflowers.htm

- AB

#WildflowerWednesday

[#ImageDescription: Vibrant pink-hued flowers burst forth from a cluster of cacti along the South Rim of the Grand Canyon. NPS Photo/M. Quinn]

node.accessibility_caption: A small collection of pink flowers, dandelion fluff, and grasses delicately rise up with awe from the earth. NPS Photo/A. Rehkopf

node.text:
Mindfulness Practice: At Our National Parks and In Life 

Our national parks provide us with an incredible opportunity to reconnect with a slowed, more intentional pace. However, if we’re used to a faster pace, our minds full, how do we switch off our brain’s autopilot function, to engage with, and be fully present, in this moment? Furthermore, how can we find acceptance, even a sense of peace, for wherever we’re at on our path?

Naturally, being here at the Grand Canyon, and across our national parks, we talk mostly of the outer landscape, but what consideration and care do we afford to our inner landscape? 

Here’s where a mindfulness practice has a lot to offer us. 

According to Jon Kabat-Zinn, “Mindfulness means paying attention in a particular way: on purpose, in the present moment, and non-judgmentally.” The key part of his statement, along with a lot of practice, is its non-judgmental component.

Mindfulness practice:
1)	Normalize the emotions you’re facing; be gentle with yourself when life feels hard. 
2)	Remember that your emotions are temporary. 
3)	What are you ready to release, or let go of, in this moment?
4)	Pause, connect with your breath, tune into one of your 5 senses.
5)	Is there something you feel grateful for in this moment?

The Grand Canyon is alive with color, diversity, and intricate detail. Pause and notice the close-up views of what’s right beneath your feet. 

To read more, visit: 
https://www.nps.gov/articles/000/mindfulness-practice-at-our-national-parks-and-in-life.htm

node.accessibility_caption: At sunset, a bolt of lightning forks before striking a silhouetted peak within a vast canyon landscape. A sheer cliff above a sloping ridgeline make up the foreground on the left. NPS/M. Quinn

node.text:
Thunderstorm across the canyon at sunset, on this Tuesday July 27, 2021.

Outside when a thunderstorm moves in? Observe the direction of storm movement, listen for thunder, watch for lightning and If the sound of thunder follows a lightning flash in 30 seconds or less, seek shelter immediately.  #AZWX #Arizona #GrandCanyon #MonsoonSeason

Image: at sunset, a bolt of lightning forks before striking a silhouetted peak within a vast canyon landscape. A sheer cliff above a sloping ridgeline make up the foreground on the left. NPS/M. Quinn

node.accessibility_caption: Glorious sunrise views from Indian Garden with an overlay of a quote by Sri Sri Ravi Shankar. NPS Photo/K. Hensel

node.text:
“Wisdom is knowing when to have rest, when to have activity, and how much of each to have.” — Sri Sri Ravi Shankar

Have you been feeling hot and bothered with this summertime heat? Whether you’re feeling bothered or hot, or neither or both, on this Mindful Monday, we wanted to highlight the Mindfulness work that some of our Inner Canyon Rangers are providing for visitors.

The Grand Canyon is a very unique place, full of extremes. From the weather to the terrain to how all of us humans react to those things. Especially in the summer, burnout can tap our deepest energy resources if we don't make space to rest.

On an average workday, our Rangers encounter people caught up in extreme emotions facing an environment out of their control. But our Rangers experience similarly strong emotions when they are processing the stressors of emergency response. So how do they cope? 

Our Inner Canyon Rangers have some Mindfulness Tools to share with us: 
1)	It’s important to normalize the emotions we are facing.
2)	Using positive self-affirmation: “Being gentle with myself when life is hard.”
3)	Pause and use one of your 5 senses to explore the canyon.

Close your eyes and remember the last time you felt well-rested and peaceful. What are you grateful for in this moment? 💜

#MindfulMonday #Mindfulness #StressRelief #Calm #Interpretation #ParkRanger

node.accessibility_caption: Glorious sunrise views from Indian Garden with an overlay of a quote by Sri Sri Ravi Shankar. NPS Photo/K. Hensel
A park ranger leads a group of visitors in a seated mindfulness practice amidst some trees in the inner canyon. NPS Photo/K. Pitts
A group of people sit near their campground in the inner canyon as a park ranger guides them in a mindfulness practice. NPS Photo/K. Hensel
a watercolor painting from inside a large canyon, with small shrubs and 2 car-sized boulders on a ledge overlooking a muddy river that is flowing beneath colorful cliffs.

node.text:
"Grand Canyon 1929" by Gunnar Widforss 
Watercolor on canvas board. H 16 in (43 cm) W 20 in (53.2 cm)
Grand Canyon National Park, 13631

Swedish-born artist Gunnar Widforss first traveled to the Southwest in 1923 and began painting landscapes of Western national parks. He lived at the South Rim of Grand Canyon for several years and during this time, produced many paintings depicting park scenes. 

Applications are now open for next year's Grand Canyon Artist in Residence! We are seeking professional artists working at a high level in their discipline who can give new insights and focus to Grand Canyon and the surrounding communities as an on-site resident artist at Grand Canyon National Park. The deadline to apply for 2022 is September 15, 2021.

Details: grandcanyon.org/artist  @grand_canyon_conservancy
 
#GrandCanyon #Arizona #Watercolor #Art #ArtOfInstagram #ArtistInResidence #ArtistInResidenceProgram 

image: a watercolor painting from inside a large canyon, with small shrubs and 2 car-sized boulders on a ledge overlooking a muddy river that is flowing beneath colorful cliffs.

node.accessibility_caption: summer clouds forming across the sky above a mile deep canyon filled with colorful peaks and cliffs. In the distance, on the left, rain is falling within the canyon. NPS/M. Quinn

node.text:
Distant rain showers within the canyon at 4:11 pm. The view is from the Trail of Time on the South Rim, just east of Verkamp's Visitor Center. After a mostly sunny afternoon, it started to rain in the village around 8 pm. (Saturday, July 24, 2021)

Monsoonal thunderstorms move through Arizona offering beauty, excitement, and much-needed water, but dangerous and potentially deadly lightning accompanies them. Reduce your risk and learn how to avoid lightning dangers by practicing basic safety precautions. go.nps.gov/gc-lightning

#Arizona #GrandCanyon #AZWX #EarthFocus #SummerAfternoon

Image: summer clouds forming across the sky above a mile deep canyon filled with colorful peaks and cliffs. In the distance, on the left, rain is falling within the canyon. NPS/M. Quinn

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on July 23, 2021. May be an image of tree, sky and text.

node.text:
Moving into the weekend with some #FridayThoughts. 🌌

What makes you come alive with curiosity? 🔎💕

- AB

NPS Photo
[#ImageDescription: The Milky Way galaxy rises above a series of tree silhouettes with an overlay of a quote by Stephen Hawking: “Remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet. Try to make sense of what you see and wonder about what makes the universe exist. Be curious.”]

node.accessibility_caption: Evening views across a stormy canyon with lightning seen in the distance. NPS Photo/M. Quinn

node.text:
🚨 Heavy Rains and Thunderstorms forecasted through Monday, July 26th. Flash Flood Warning in Effect. 🚨

Monsoon season can mean conditions go from mild to wild, real quick! Monsoon weather can include sudden flash flooding, frequent lightning strikes, hail storms, torrential rains, and strong gusts of winds. ⛈⚡️💨

ℹ️ 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐔𝐩𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐞: The Bright Angel trail is open to foot traffic, in both directions. There may be short delays at some new rock slide areas, while our trail crews are working to remove debris. Currently, there are no mule trips on the Bright Angel trail until these slides are cleared. Trail crew estimates that they can clear the trail today, but that is highly dependent on today’s weather. Therefore, hikers should be prepared for debris, rock slides, and washed out sections of the trail as storms move through this area through the weekend.

⚠️ 𝐀𝐝𝐝𝐞𝐝 𝐂𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐧 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐬: The upper sections of trail are the most dangerous as these are more exposed areas and lightning tends to splash across the Kaibab Limestone. Additionally, the ground can be very unstable (saturated and constantly moving) and rock fall is a major hazard. Each year we have people get hit by rock fall, so stopping in safe locations and being very aware of your surroundings is paramount. 

👂 𝐋𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐁𝐞 𝐀𝐥𝐞𝐫𝐭: Listen for thunder, watch for lightning, and observe the direction of storm movement. Be vigilant of possible flash floods or falling rocks during or after storms. 

🏚 𝐒𝐞𝐞𝐤 𝐒𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐭𝐞𝐫: Move away from the canyon edge; leave open areas immediately; and avoid rocky outcrops, lone trees, the tallest trees, poles, railings, and bodies of water. Get to a shelter—building, vehicle with the windows closed—as quickly as possible. Do not touch rock walls or any metal on vehicles or structures. 

🧎 𝐈𝐟 𝐍𝐨 𝐈𝐦𝐦𝐞𝐝𝐢𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐒𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐭𝐞𝐫: If in an open area, such as a trail, crouch on the balls of your feet with your heels touching, head down, and hands covering ears. Your hands should not touch the ground. Do not lie flat on the ground.

node.accessibility_caption: A painting captures the canyon's interior after a thunderstorm, with storm clouds parting and golden light illuminating canyon peaks and buttes.

node.text:
"Flaming Finale" by Ralph Love - Oil on canvas. W 36 in x H 23 in. (1960's). Born in Los Angeles, Love spent his entire life in California. A primarily self-taught artist, he is well-known for his depictions of Grand Canyon. 

Applications are now open for next year's Grand Canyon Artist in Residence! We are seeking professional artists working at a high level in their discipline who can give new insights and focus to Grand Canyon and the surrounding communities as an on-site resident artist at Grand Canyon National Park. The deadline to apply for 2022 is September 15, 2021. 

Visit  grandcanyon.org/artist  for details.

Image: A painting captures the canyon's interior after a thunderstorm, with storm clouds parting and golden light illuminating canyon peaks and buttes.
